data.text: There are a lot of overly worried people here. Too many "what ifs" from people who don't do long distance touring but drive cars with hydraulic brakes‚Ä¶ I'm on tour for 5 continuous years this August. I guess you can say I'm an experienced tourer. I NEVER had a hydraulic brake fail or need repair or maintenance. If one failed, guess what? You have 2. You can go countless miles on 1 brake cos you have NO CHOICE, you will not be riding steep mountains until you fix it, right? The only maintenance I do is I replace pads about once a year. I ride in a lot of remote places, high mountains, and steep roads (steepest so far was 29 degrees in Turkey). I've been to countries that are stereotyped to not have parts like Africa, SE Asia, India, S America. Nonsense. Every big city has "fancy" bike shops because even people in India for example have the means to buy "expensive" bikes to travel the world with‚Ä¶ It's not just Americans or Western Europeans that have "special" bikes with hydraulic brakes, large tires, etc. Regardless, the world is pretty small these days. Anything can be shipped anywhere. Rohloff will ship a replacement hub for free ANYWHERE you are in the world if it fails you. The sun will always shine after a storm. That's part of touring. Shit hits the fan. Things get lost, forgotten, stolen, or break. Everything is replaceable or fixable. Even in the most remote places, there will be people to help you. *If you are going to tour for a few months or longer, learn how to fix every part of your bike and carry the tools and spare parts like pads, chain, lube, etc. Don't fall for the ultra light hype. Tools and parts are essential even if you'll never use them! Even if you'll be riding in your home country. The US is big. It can be many hundreds of miles before there will be a bike shop to save you. If a back spoke breaks for example, you'd be happy you carried the cassette remover tools. For long tours (months or years), you will be at 40-60kg (70-130lbs) - bike + gear + food and water. Another 1 kilo/lbs, won't make any difference to your daily average distance. NOT A SINGLE DIFFERENCE.

With 55-60kg (bike + gear + food/water), going down hill up to 79.7kph on paved roads (haven't broke 80 yet), it's nice to be able to drop speed to 20kph in a few short meters before those 180 degree U turns compared to cable breaks. data.text: Disc brakes are great. There are cable discs, cable hydraulic discs and full hydraulic discs. The cable hydraulic discs are easily maintained. ( no hydraulic lines to damage) the full hydraulics discs are possible the most powerful. Also very smooth to operate. As long as the pads are in good condition, there is no reason not to do a long tour (1000 miles or so ) with them. The pads are very easy to change when they are worn out. Another big advantage is that should you have a mishap and buckle a wheel you can continue without the brake continually rubbing yhr rim until you can get the wheel trued. As far as I am concerned the only downside is that the are noisy when yhe discs get wet. I can put up with that though.
